text: JULY 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 1    Defined as the safe, ethical and effective management of data. For more information, see the working draft OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: 2   A literature review of 55 publicly available guidance documents informing responsible data management across the humanitarian sector revealed 22
label: BODY

text: different approaches, included as tools or recommended in the guidance document. The literature review is available from the Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data (“The Centre”) upon request.
label: BODY

text: 3   Positive implications of data management are usually referred to as ‘benefits’, while negative implications include risks and harms — with rights
label: BODY

text: infringements often called out specifically.
label: BODY

text: 4   DIAs contribute to Data Protection by Design or Privacy by Design if they are conducted at the outset of the development or use of a new tool or
label: BODY

text: architecture. For more information, see for example Privacy By Design, The 7 Foundational Principles.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: SÉRIE DE NOTES D’ORIENTATION
label: HH1

text: LA RESPONSABILITÉ DES DONNÉES DANS L’ACTION HUMANITAIRE
label: HH1

text: DATA IMPACT ASSESSMENTS
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Data Impact Assessments (DIAs) determine the potential benefits and risks associated with data
label: BODY

text: management. They are a critical component of responsible data management, but are often
label: BODY

text: overlooked.
label: BODY

text: •	 There are a wide variety of approaches to DIAs. Selecting the right assessment for a given data
label: BODY

text: management activity can help minimize the risks and maximize the benefits to affected people,
label: BODY

text: humanitarians and other stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: •	 Applicable laws and regulations, internal policies, the context in which data management
label: BODY

text: will take place and other factors determine which assessment(s) should be applied to a data
label: BODY

text: management activity.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data impact assessments should be conducted before and during data management activities in
label: BODY

text: order to  inform project planning and design. Activities should be redesigned or cancelled if the
label: BODY

text: foreseeable risks of data management outweigh the intended benefits.
label: BODY

text: DATA IMPACT ASSESSMENTS
label: HH1

text: Guidance on data responsibility1 in humanitarian action often contains tools for conducting Data Impact
label: BODY

text: Assessments (‘DIAs’ or ‘assessments’). The purpose of conducting a DIA is to understand the positive
label: BODY

text: and negative consequences of a data management activity. DIAs are a key component of accountability
label: BODY

text: mechanisms and can serve to demonstrate compliance with applicable law, regulations, internal policies
label: BODY

text: and other guidance.2 Even when not obligatory, a DIA is advisable to help maximize benefits and minimize
label: BODY

text: risks associated with operational data management.3
label: BODY

text: Operational data management includes the design of data management activities and subsequent
label: BODY

text: collection or receipt, storage, processing, analysis, sharing, use, and retention and destruction of data and
label: BODY

text: information by humanitarian actors. Examples of common data management activities are registration
label: BODY

text: exercises and protection monitoring.
label: BODY

text: DIA outcomes may require that an activity be redesigned or cancelled if the foreseeable risks of data
label: BODY

text: management outweigh the intended benefits.4 Common risks associated with data management include
label: BODY

text: privacy infringements to individuals and groups, affected people being exposed to physical harm or
label: BODY

text: persecution, or the risk of misrepresentation and poorly informed decision-making. Common benefits of
label: BODY

text: data management activities include better targeting of humanitarian assistance to those in need,
label: BODY

text: preventing inefficiency or waste by improved tracking of aid delivery and more detailed understanding of a
label: BODY

text: crisis situation.
label: BODY

text: JULY 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 5    The International Standardization Organization (ISO) defines risk as ‘the effect of uncertainty on objectives’, which is ‘usually expressed in terms of
label: BODY

text: risk sources, potential events, their consequences and their likelihood.’ See the ISO 31000:2018 Risk Management Guidance.
label: BODY

text: 6  See for example the United Nations Global Pulse Risks, Harms and Benefits Assessment tool.
label: BODY

text: 7  For an example of a Data Protection Impact Assessment template, see Brussels Privacy Hub (VUB) and International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)
label: BODY

text: Handbook on Data Protection in Humanitarian Action (2nd edition), 2020, p. 299.
label: BODY

text: 8    See for example the OHCHR Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and for an example of a human rights centered approach, this
label: BODY

text: report on the role of new technologies for the realization of economic, social and cultural rights (in particular para. 46).
label: BODY

text: TYPOLOGY OF ASSESSMENTS
label: HH1

text: There are many different approaches to DIAs. Some of the most common include: Risk Assessments; Risks,
label: BODY

text: Harms and Benefits Assessments; Human Rights Impact Assessments; and Data Protection or Privacy
label: BODY

text: Impact Assessments.
label: BODY

text: Even assessments with similar names can cover different focus areas. For example, a Risk Assessment
label: BODY

text: for one organization may be broad and cover physical risk to individuals as well as potential rights
label: BODY

text: infringements and even expected benefits of data management activities. Other Risk Assessments are
label: BODY

text: focused only on the potential negative consequences of data management activities. The differences
label: BODY

text: between these approaches can often be explained by the sector or field in which they were developed.
label: BODY

text: FOCUS AREAS
label: HH1

text: Organisations should consider the following focus areas when selecting a model or tool for undertaking the
label: BODY

text: assessment:
label: BODY

text: •	 Risk is the likelihood and impact of harm resulting from operational data management.5 Risk is
label: HH1

text: included as a focus area in most DIAs.
label: BODY

text: •	 Harm consists of a negative consequence of a data management activity for an individual or group of
label: BODY

text: individuals. DIAs typically cover harms such as physical harm to individuals, stigmatization of groups
label: BODY

text: and the impairment of aid delivery. Such harm can impact different stakeholders, including affected
label: BODY

text: people and aid workers.
label: BODY

text: •	 Benefit relates to the potential positive impact of data management, often measured in the provision
label: HH1

text: of humanitarian aid or resource efficiency gains.6 Operational data management can benefit various
label: BODY

text: stakeholders, with an inherent focus on affected people.
label: BODY

text: •	 Privacy involves determining whether individual (and sometimes group) privacy is respected in data
label: HH1

text: management. This focus area often relates to applicable rules or legislation.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data protection comprises a broader set of laws and regulations regarding data management,
label: HH1

text: including the protection of privacy. Like the privacy focus area, this often relates to applicable rules or
label: BODY

text: legislation.7
label: BODY

text: •	 Human rights covers fundamental rights including the right to privacy, the right to life and other
label: BODY

text: rights that are relevant in humanitarian response situations.8
label: BODY

text: DIAs can take into account one or more of these focus areas. Variations reflect the applicability of legal
label: BODY

text: frameworks, organizational priorities and other factors, and can mean that one assessment is better suited
label: BODY

text: than others in a given context.
label: BODY

text: Answer the following questions to determine whether an assessment is needed and if so, which areas to
label: BODY

text: focus on:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Is a specific assessment required by applicable laws and regulations?
label: HH1

text: Applicable laws and regulations will often prescribe that an assessment should be conducted and
label: BODY

text: which focus areas should be included. Required DIAs may be supplemented by additional steps,
label: BODY

text: either taken from existing templates or designed for the data management activity at hand.
label: BODY

text: DECIDING TO DO AN ASSESSMENT
label: HH1

text: JULY 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 9   See for an example of a template Data Impact Assessment this RFL template for National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.
label: BODY

text: 10 The UN Global Pulse tool is grounded in the UN Principles on Personal Data Protection and Privacy and UNSDG Guidance Note on Data Privacy,
label: BODY

text: Data Protection and Data Ethics as well as other relevant international instruments.
label: BODY

text: 11   Brussels Privacy Hub (VUB) and International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) Handbook on Data Protection in Humanitarian Action (2nd
label: BODY

text: edition), 2020, p. 299.
label: BODY

text: 12  RFL template for National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Do internal organisational policies require that a specific assessment be conducted?
label: HH1

text: Where internal guidance regarding the preparation for data management activities is available,
label: BODY

text: always follow such guidance. Depending on the circumstances of the activity, additional steps may be
label: BODY

text: added to mandatory assessments.9
label: BODY

text: 3.	Does the activity entail the management of sensitive data?
label: HH1

text: Data is classified as sensitive based on the likelihood and severity of potential harm that may
label: BODY

text: materialize as a result of its exposure in a particular context. Both personal and non-personal data
label: BODY

text: can be sensitive. A DIA should always be conducted if such data is likely to be managed in a given
label: BODY

text: activity.
label: BODY

text: 4.	Is data management taking place in a particularly sensitive response context?
label: HH1

text: Incertain operational settings, humanitarian data management activities warrant additional caution.
label: BODY

text: A context can be sensitive due to specific vulnerabilities of affected people, the value of their data to
label: BODY

text: parties that may wish to subject them to harm or the legal obligations — lawful or unlawful — with
label: BODY

text: which the actors involved must comply. Where private actors are involved, consider issues around
label: BODY

text: data access, governance and ownership.
label: BODY

text: 5.	Will the data management activity be systematic or large-scale?
label: HH1

text: Systematic and/or large-scale data management activities require assessments that account for a
label: BODY

text: longer timeframe and include plans to update or repeat the assessment at a later stage. Examples
label: BODY

text: include annual Multi-Cluster Needs Assessments or a country-wide beneficiary registration system.
label: BODY

text: If any of these questions is answered with ‘yes’, an assessment should be conducted. Even if the answer to
label: BODY

text: each of these questions is ‘no’, a creating a basic list of benefits and risks associated with the data
label: BODY

text: management activity is still recommended.
label: BODY

text: Always check to see if an assessment has been conducted previously for a linked or similar data
label: BODY

text: management activity. This will help inform whether a DIA covering all relevant focus areas is still needed
label: BODY

text: for the current activity or whether gaps between the two activities can be assessed instead. Any other
label: BODY

text: relevant information regarding the similar data management activity — such as a past data breach —
label: BODY

text: should be taken into account when conducting a DIA of the new activity.
label: BODY

text: TOOLS FOR ASSESSMENTS
label: HH1

text: While there is no single approach to DIAs across the humanitarian sector, there are various publicly
label: BODY

text: available tools and templates that can be adapted by humanitarians. Notable examples include the
label: BODY

text: following:
label: BODY

text: •	 UN Global Pulse has developed a Risk, Harms and Benefits Assessment tool, which focuses on data
label: BODY

text: protection, privacy and ethics. It is designed to assess data and artificial intelligence innovation
label: BODY

text: projects. The tool is a combination of a human rights and data privacy impact assessment.10
label: BODY

text: •	 The International Committee of the Red Cross and the Brussels Privacy Hub promote the use of a Data
label: BODY

text: Protection Impact Assessment. The template can be found in the second edition of their Handbook on
label: BODY

text: Data Protection in Humanitarian Action.11
label: BODY

text: •	 The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement uses a data impact assessment that is
label: BODY

text: focused on data protection when restoring family links.12
label: BODY

text: JULY 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 13  Privacy International and ICRC report ‘The Humanitarian Metadata Problem: “Doing No Harm” In The Digital Era’, October 2018.
label: BODY

text: Mapping structures in refugee settlements with satellite imagery
label: BODY

text: UN Global Pulse
label: BODY

text: UN Global Pulse used its Risk, Harms and Benefits Assessment in a project involving the use of satellite
label: BODY

text: imagery assisted by neural networks to map structures in refugee settlements. The assessment was
label: BODY

text: undertaken by a diverse team of experts, from legal and policy specialists to technical and programme
label: BODY

text: staff.
label: BODY

text: The assessment highlighted that satellite imagery could be used to reveal the location of vulnerable
label: BODY

text: groups of individuals in refugee camps. Malicious actors may be able to undertake harmful misuse
label: BODY

text: of the analysis resulting in potential fundamental rights violations and other harms. Knowing the
label: BODY

text: location of individuals in a conflict setting could lead to persecution, discrimination, physical harm or
label: BODY

text: even death. Possible algorithmic failure or bias could result in certain groups of individuals being left
label: BODY

text: unaccounted for and without assistance.
label: BODY

text: As a result of the assessment, the team identified mitigation measures that included reviewing the
label: BODY

text: security and retention measures of the data, algorithm training for personnel, and policy clarifications,
label: BODY

text: such as placing limits on public release of results. The risks were regularly re-evaluated throughout
label: BODY

text: the project as the technology and data sources evolved.
label: BODY

text: CONDUCTING THE ASSESSMENT
label: HH1

text: The following steps will help organizations ensure that a DIA is successful:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Involve internal and external stakeholders with the right expertise
label: HH1

text: The roles and expertise needed to design and apply the DIA will vary based on the type of assessment,
label: BODY

text: as well as the type and scale of the activity that will be assessed. Relevant expertise includes:
label: BODY

text: •	 Legal and compliance expertise in data protection, privacy and human rights
label: BODY

text: •	 Technical understanding of the data management activity
label: BODY

text: •	 Knowledge of the context in which the data management activity is taking place
label: BODY

text: 2.	Clarify the consequences of possible assessment outcomes
label: HH1

text: Define the potential outcomes and their consequences ahead of the DIA. An assessment typically
label: BODY

text: leads to any of the following outcomes:
label: BODY

text: A.	The negative consequences associated with data management are non-existent or negligible. In
label: BODY

text: these cases, the data management activity can continue.
label: BODY

text: B.	The negative consequences are minimal and can be mitigated to be in balance with expected
label: BODY

text: benefits.
label: BODY

text: C.	The negative consequences are unacceptable. To continue, the design of the data management
label: BODY

text: activity should be revisited. Once negative consequences are brought into balance with the
label: BODY

text: expected benefits, the activity can continue.
label: BODY

text: D.	The negative consequences are unacceptable and cannot be mitigated. In such cases, the data
label: BODY

text: management activity should be cancelled.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Adapt the assessment to the context
label: HH1

text: The assessment may need to be adapted to the context in which the data management activity takes
label: BODY

text: place. This involves adding additional focus areas as needed in order to assess  context-specific risks
label: BODY

text: or concerns of affected people.13
label: BODY

text: JULY 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: 4.	Determine when to reassess
label: HH1

text: Since data management and the context in which it takes place are not static, regular reassessments
label: BODY

text: should be scheduled at the outset of an activity. The conditions under which a reassessment may be
label: BODY

text: required — such as a significant change in data management or the context in which it takes place —
label: BODY

text: should also be determined.
label: BODY

text: 5.	Make a distribution plan
label: HH1

text: Decide who should be able to access the assessment results and be clear about how the results will be
label: BODY

text: shared with different audiences.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING THE USE OF DIAS
label: HH1

text: The Centre and the collaborators on this guidance note recommend that organizations focus on the
label: BODY

text: following areas to improve the use of DIAs for operational data management:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Designing standard assessment tools
label: HH1

text: Taking a standardized approach to DIAs and adjusting it for the given context reduces friction and
label: BODY

text: saves time. Organizations can draw on commonly used and established assessment tools to design
label: BODY

text: their own standard approach. Submitting a tool for internal legal and management review and
label: BODY

text: endorsement helps streamline its future use.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Develop the capacity to conduct assessments
label: HH1

text: Identifying, developing and updating the skills required for assessments helps prevent delays in
label: BODY

text: conducting DIAs and reduces the chance of flawed or incomplete assessment outcomes.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Share data impact assessment results
label: HH1

text: Assessment results should be shared to the extent possible and as long as it does not expose
label: BODY

text: confidential or otherwise sensitive information.
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in assessing the positive and negative
label: BODY

text: consequences of operational data management with the Centre via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: COLLABORATORS: UN GLOBAL PULSE; THE INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE OF THE RED CROSS; PRIVACY INTERNATIONAL.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
